head.title: CNN and YouTube Keep Reporters Dangling

If the news conference that CNN and YouTube held last week to discuss their first-of-a-kind presidential debate was any sort of omen, there might be a few kinks for the companies to work out in the months ahead.

Ahead of a conference call Thursday, the companies sent the wrong dial-in number to many journalists, leaving about a dozen of them listening to dead air while colleagues call continued on another line.

After the fact, there was some finger-pointing, but no official explanation of how the lines of communications had been crossed. Reporters who missed the first 15 minutes or so of the news conference could get an e-mail transcript.

Those who had the correct telephone number heard senior executives from CNN and YouTube talk about the new ground rules: Ordinary folk are being invited to post videos on YouTube with questions for the candidates, and the best of the questions will be selected for a July 23 event featuring the Democrats. A similar forum for Republican candidates will be held on Sept. 17.

''We're confident we're providing a new outlet for them for distribution,'' said Chad Hurley, chief executive and co-founder of YouTube, a division of Google. ''We're actively working to provide them new opportunities and develop new technologies.''
At the first debate, Anderson Cooper of CNN will act as a moderator and pose follow-up questions; the original pool of questions will come from the public.
In the anything-goes world of YouTube, the companies expect to see creative and maybe emotional clips that will stir the audience and perhaps the candidates.
CNN and YouTube say they are trying to drive political dialogue by replacing the old scripted format and putting power into the hands of everyday citizens.

''This is the most democratic of all possible structures,'' said David Bohrman, senior vice president and Washington bureau chief of CNN. ''Everyone in the country has a chance of having a question asked of someone who can very possibly be the next president.''
As for ironing out any possible glitches or communication problems before the debate, CNN said it was sure everything would be organized and ready.
''We don't normally handle the press conferences,'' Mr. Bohrman said. ''But we are running the debates, so the audience shouldn't worry.''
